    • Constructor Detail

      • StudyGroupTest.TestObject

        public StudyGroupTest.TestObject()
        This uses the default constructor of the tested class.

      • StudyGroupTest.TestObject

        public StudyGroupTest.TestObject(java.lang.Object argument)
        This uses the constructor in the tested class that takes only one argument. If no such constructor can be found or another exception occurs during instantiation, Assert.fail(String) will be called and output a detailed error message.
        Parameters:
        argument - The argument to be passed to the constructor of the tested class.

      • StudyGroupTest.TestObject

        public StudyGroupTest.TestObject(java.lang.Object[] arguments)
        This is for a constructor in the tested class that takes more than one argument. Each Object in argument is used as one parameter for the constructor of the tested class. This constructor will try to automatically select the right constructor of the tested class by the classes of the passed arguments. If no such constructor can be found or another exception occurs during instantiation, Assert.fail(String) will be called and output a detailed error message.
        This constructor will assume for any Object that is an instance of a elementary data type class, that an elementary data type was meant.
        If this constructor fails to find (or select the right) constructor of the tested class, use #TestObject(Object[], Class[])!
        Parameters:
        arguments - The arguments to be passed to the constructor of the tested class in the correct order.

      • StudyGroupTest.TestObject

        public StudyGroupTest.TestObject(java.lang.Object[] arguments,
                         java.lang.Class<?>[] argumentTypes)
        This is the most generic constructor. If any other constructor fails to instantiate the tested class, use this one. It will find the constructor of the tested class with the formal arguments you provide in argumentTypes and call it with the arguments you provide in arguments. If no such constructor can be found or another exception occurs during instantiation, Assert.fail(String) will be called and output a detailed error message.
        In most cases, it is not necessary to use this one. #TestObject(Object[]) will do the job most of the time.
        Parameters:
        arguments - The arguments to be passed to the constructor.
        argumentTypes - The classes of the test class' constructor's formal arguments. The constructor will be selected based on the classes you provide.

    • Method Detail

      • getImplementedInstance

        public final java.lang.Object getImplementedInstance()
        You can use this to get a reference to the actual instance of the tested class. Most of the times, you won't want to do this! It is only meant for comparison of instances and such things.
        Returns:
        the "real" instance of the tested class.

      • run

        public java.lang.Object run(java.lang.String methodName)
        Runs a method that takes no arguments. If there is no such method that is named methodName, Assert.fail(String) will be called to output a detailed error message.
        Parameters:
        methodName - The name of the method you want to call.
        Returns:
        What the method returns. null if it was a void method.

      • run

        public java.lang.Object run(java.lang.String methodName,
                   java.lang.Object argument)
        Runs a method that takes only one argument. If there is no method named methodName that has object.class as only formal argument or any exception occurs while trying to run it, Assert.fail(String) will be called to output a detailed error message.
        Any passed Object that is an instance of a elementary data type class will be interpreted as an elementary data type. So you can't for example call a method that is declared as foo(Integer i) with this version of run. Because if you call run("foo", new Integer(3)), it will search for a Method foo(int) in your tested class.
        If this version of run fails to find (or select the right} method, use run(String, Object, Class).
        Parameters:
        methodName - The name of the method you want to call.
        argument - The argument (Object) you want to pass to the method. The method will be selected based on the class of this.
        Returns:
        What the method returns. null if it was a void method.

      • run

        public java.lang.Object run(java.lang.String methodName,
                   java.lang.Object argument,
                   java.lang.Class<?> argumentType)
        Runs a method that takes only one argument. If there is no method named methodName that has argumentType as only formal argument or any exception occurs while trying to run it, Assert.fail(String) will be called to output a detailed error message.
        Most of the time, you don't need to use this version of run, as run(String, Object) does the job in 98% of all cases.
        Parameters:
        methodName - The name of the method you want to call.
        argument - The argument you want to pass to the method.
        argumentType - The type of argument. The method will be selected based on this.
        Returns:
        What the method returns. null if it was a void method.

      • run

        public java.lang.Object run(java.lang.String methodName,
                   java.lang.Object[] arguments)
        Runs a method that takes multiple arguments. It will select the method based the classes of the arguments. If there is no method that is named methodName and takes the classes of arguments as formal arguments, Assert.fail(String) will be called to output a detailed error message.
        Any passed Object that is an instance of a elementary data type class will be interpreted as an elementary data type. So you can't for example call a method that is declared as foo(Integer i, Long l) with this version of run. Because if you call run("foo", new Object[]{new Integer(3), new Long(2L)}), it will search for a Method foo(int, long) in your tested class.
        If this method fails to find the right method in the tested class, use run(String, Object[], Class[])!
        Parameters:
        methodName - The name of the method you want to call.
        arguments - The arguments you want to pass to the method in the correct order.
        Returns:
        What the method returns. null if it was a void method.

      • run

        public java.lang.Object run(java.lang.String methodName,
                   java.lang.Object[] arguments,
                   java.lang.Class<?>[] argumentTypes)
        The most generic way to call a method. Runs a method that takes multiple arguments. It will search a method with the formal parameters provided in argumentTypes named methodName. If there is no such method, Assert.fail(String) will be called to output a detailed error message.
        Usually, it should not be necessary to use this method. run(String, Object[]) will do the job most of the time!
        Parameters:
        methodName - The name of the method you want to call.
        arguments - The arguments you want to pass to the method in the correct order.
        argumentTypes - The method's formal argument's classes. By them, the method will be selected.
        Returns:
        What the method returns. null if it was a void method.
